ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Roles of interface and oxide trap density in the kinked current behavior of Al/SiO2/Si(p) structures with ultra-thin oxides

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Graduate Institute of Electronics Engineering, Department of Electrical Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
A clear current kinked phenomenon was observed in Al/SiO2/Si(p) structures with nanoscale (<2.5 nm) SiO2 in a forward biased region. It was found that the kinked points are dependent on oxide thickness and are not the same as flat-band voltages. A model regarding the oxide voltage dropping efficiency with the consideration of interface trap density (
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ ) and effective charge number density (
Q eff
/ q
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}/q$ ) was proposed for the observation. It is noted that the kinked point is severely affected by the oxide quality and uniformity. However, Al/SiO2/Si(n) structures in a forward biased region do not exhibit this current kinked phenomenon because the dropping behavior of oxide is absolutely different from Al/SiO2/Si(p) structures.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Trap densities are some of the main determinants of device performance. Many studies in thin-film transistors (TFTs) related to in-film trap density [1–5] and in-film and insulator-interface trap densities [6–9] have been reported. They indicate that the improvement of device characteristics is due to the reduction of trap densities. Therefore, it is important to extract trap densities in order to evaluate film properties, improve transistor performance, and diagnose fabrication processes.

The downscaling trend in metal–oxide–semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET) devices is accompanied by an exponential increase of the leakage current through the gate oxide. In MOSFET structures with ultra-thin oxide films, the potential barrier between the gate and the silicon substrate cannot be considered as impenetrable anymore and it is verified that the direct tunneling dominates the gate leakage current and the off-state power dissipation of the transistor [10–13]. It is known that SiO2 is widely accepted as an excellent gate insulator in MOS structures [14] mainly due to its relatively high energy barrier at the electrode interfaces and the ease of its fabrication. Moreover, the technique of the current density–voltage (
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ ) measurement has been widely adopted to investigate the electrical characteristics in semiconductor devices and is still indispensable with the trend of the scaling down in feature size since it helps us greatly to gain insight into the fundamental physical mechanisms. For these reasons, to study the gate current behavior in Al/SiO2/Si MOS structures with different substrates in ultra-thin oxide regime is of importance.

By observation, it is obvious to see a “kinked point” in a forward biased region of every
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve of Al/SiO2/Si(p) MOS, i.e., MOS(p), structure with different oxide thickness. When gate bias is increasing, the current density will not increase smoothly but bend around
− 1 V
$-1\mbox{~V}$ . It is an inherent physical phenomenon in MOS(p) devices and needs a detailed examination of its origin. Therefore, a deeper understanding of the main current mechanism is of necessity. First, we try to extract these kinked points of various oxide thicknesses from
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curves. It is noted that these kinked point voltages are not the same as flat-band voltages (
V FB
$V_{\mathrm{FB}}$ ). Therefore, a comprehensive study of the origin of kinked points is carried out. It is suggested that the roles of interface trap density (
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ ) and oxide charge are important to the relationship between the silicon surface potential (
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ ) and the silicon oxide voltage (
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ ) versus the applied gate voltage (
V G
$V_{G}$ ). A distinct change of the dominant role from
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ to
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ was observed when the Al/SiO2/Si(p) capacitor was biased from small to large forward biased conditions. It is related to the proportion of the potential drops on the insulator, SiO2. Finally, a strong agreement between the simulation results and the extracted experimental kinked points for gate oxide has been achieved. Also, the comparison study on the
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve of Al/SiO2/Si(n) MOS structure is conducted. In a forward biased region, the current density increases smoothly with bias without any kinks. A detailed examination by employing the energy band diagram is given. By our analysis of leakage current in the nanoscale silicon oxide layer, it is believed that a comprehensive understanding of the kinked phenomenon of gate current is obtained and the trap densities are of quite an importance.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
3-inch, p- and n-type (100)-oriented silicon wafers with a resistivity of 1–10
Ω
$\Omega$ cm were used as the substrates of MOS capacitors. After the standard RCA cleaning process, ultra-thin dielectric, SiO2, was grown by room-temperature anodic oxidation method [15–21] in D.I. water with the silicon wafer as anode and the platinum plate as cathode. The cathode platinum plate was tilted in a particular angle to obtain different thickness of SiO2 on one wafer at one time. For the sake of reducing interface trap and oxide charge densities, rapid thermal annealing in
N 2
$\mathrm{N}_{2}$ ambient at 950 °C for 15 s was carried out. Subsequently, the aluminum (Al) gate electrode was evaporated on the wafer and then patterned by photolithography with a defined area of
2.25 ×
10
− 4
cm 2
$2.25\times10^{-4}\mbox{~cm}^{2}$ . After removing the back native oxide by buffered oxide etchant (BOE), the aluminum film was evaporated again to be a back contact of MOS capacitor.

The capacitance–voltage (
C
$C$ –
V
$V$ ) and current–voltage (
I
$I$ –
V
$V$ ) characteristics were measured by an HP4284 LCR meter and an HP4140B pA, respectively. Oxide thickness, tox, was extracted by two-frequency-corrected capacitance measurement of 100 kHz and 1 MHz under the consideration of quantum mechanical effect [22].

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curves of (a) MOS(p) and (b) MOS(n) capacitors under forward biased conditions with oxide thicknesses varying from 1.8 to 2.3 nm.
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve represents the ability of oxide to block the gate leakage current. As expected, the thinner oxide has the larger leakage current density due to the raise of tunneling probability. Moreover, we find out an interesting phenomenon in MOS(p) capacitors just as the dashed square points out, shown in Fig. 1(a). When the gate voltage sweeps from 0 V to negative bias, the increasing rate of gate current density will slow down first and then speed up continuously in every
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve of different oxide thicknesses. In other words, every
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve does not increase smoothly but “kinks” around that region. However, this kinked phenomenon does not appear in MOS(n) capacitors, shown in Fig. 1(b). The increasing rate of gate current density will speed up continuously without any kinks in every
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve of different oxide thickness. That is, every
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve increases smoothly with gate voltage.
Fig. 1
The gate current density of (a) MOS(p) and (b) MOS(n) capacitors with ultra-thin SiO2 films in the thickness range of 1.8–2.3 nm. A clear kinked phenomenon in every
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve can be seen in MOS(p) capacitor. The minimum differentiating values (
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ ) correspond to the kinked points. Compared to MOS(p) capacitor, there is no kinked phenomenon in MOS(n) capacitor

To study this characteristic, we try to draw out these “kinked points” of all oxide thicknesses in MOS(p) capacitors. By differentiating the gate current density versus gate voltage, just as expected in this
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve kinked region, it is our intentional to get a minimum derivative of gate current density corresponding to every oxide thickness. In this work, the gate bias at the minimum derivative of gate current density is denoted as
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ , equal to the kinked point indicated in Fig. 1(a). The values of extracted
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ with different oxide thicknesses are shown in Fig. 6 and explained later. It is noted that
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ is more negative than
V FB
$V_{\mathrm{FB}}$ . Therefore some physics are left behind
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ . In this work, we study the origin of
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ in detail with the consideration of
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ and effective oxide charge (
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ ). On the other hand, by differentiating the gate current density versus gate voltage for MOS(n) capacitors, certainly there is no minimum derivative, as is shown in Fig. 1(b).

In foregoing researches [23, 24], the gate current in metal–insulator–metal (MIM) structure will increase smoothly without any kinks when the bias is applied on the device raised due to the symmetrical structure. Differently from the
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve in MIM structure, it shows an apparent kink of the
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve in MOS(p) structure when the metal gate is biased around −1 V as shown in Fig. 1(a). It is reasonable to suspect that it is related to the unsymmetrical structure between the metal aluminum and substrate silicon, that is,
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ has to be taken into consideration. In MOS(p) case, not only the gate oxide but also the silicon surface will have potential drops.
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ and
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ are competing with each other following the
V G
$V_{G}$ and will be in a growth or decline relationship. However, the roles of
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ and
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ are generally not considered in estimating the kinked point. In the following, schematic energy band diagrams of MOS(p) capacitor with the consideration of
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ and
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ are adopted for the explanation of the assumption mentioned above.

Figure 2(a) is the energy band diagram of the MOS(p) capacitor under (1)
V G
= 0
$V_{G}=0$ , (2) flat-band, (3) light accumulation, and (4) strong accumulation, conditions. There is a change of the direction of band bending. When the capacitor is at the thermal equilibrium state (0 V), the silicon substrate is inverted. As the forward bias increases (from 0 to
− 1
V
$-1~\mbox{V}$ ), the silicon substrate transits from inversion to depletion to flat-band (around
− 0.86
V
$-0.86~\mbox{V}$ , in this case) and then light accumulation region. At this transition region from inversion to light accumulation, the voltage drops on the silicon substrate cannot be ignored. The
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ changes rapidly with the applied voltage. On the other hand, the proportion of the potential drop on the insulator, SiO2, is relatively small compared with the potential drop on the silicon. The tunneling probability is lightly dependent on the applied voltage at this small forward bias region. Hence, the current density changes slowly with the gate voltage. As the silicon substrate enters into accumulation region and continues to be applied with forward bias (from −1 to −2.5 V), the silicon valance band edge will be pinned to the Fermi level on the surface since majority of carriers are accumulated at the silicon surface. That is,
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ is almost keeping constant and does not have any more increment in potential drops. At this time, most of the applied voltage was dropped on the gate oxide and the electric field of gate oxide will increase tremendously. Therefore, the tunneling probability is strongly dependent on the applied voltage at this large forward bias region and the current density also changes rapidly with the gate voltage. It is noticed that the amount of interface trap charge (
Q it
$Q_{\mathrm{it}}$ ) changes with bias as observed in Fig. 2(a). The role of
Q it
$Q_{\mathrm{it}}$ in addition to
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ cannot be ignored in evaluating
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ .
Fig. 2
Schematic energy band diagrams of (a) MOS(p) and (b) MOS(n) capacitors under forward biased conditions. There is a change of the direction of band bending in MOS(p) capacitor, but no change in MOS(n) capacitor. When
|
V G

$|V_{G}|$ is larger than

$\varPsi_{S}$ ) is almost constant and the bias nearly drops on SiO2

Figure 2(b) shows the energy band diagram of the MOS(n) capacitor under (1)
V G
= 0
$V_{G} =0$ , and (2) strong accumulation, conditions. There is no change of the direction of band bending in the forward bias region. When the capacitor is at the thermal equilibrium state (0 V), differently from MOS(p), the n-silicon substrate is accumulated. The forward bias for MOS(n) is always accumulated while for MOS(p) it is depleted, flat-band, and then accumulated. Hence, as MOS(n) is at the thermal equilibrium state, the conduction band edge is already pinned by Fermi level on the surface, while
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ keeps almost constant and does not have more potential drops when
V G
$V_{G}$ increases. That is the reason why the electric field of gate oxide and the gate current density of MOS(n) will increase smoothly all the time at the forward bias.

Based on the above description, we consider
V G
@
E FS
=
E C
$V_{G}@E_{\mathrm{FS}}=E_{C}$ or
V G
@
E FS
=
E V
$V_{G}@E_{\mathrm{FS}}=E_{V}$ being the inception point that
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ almost keeps constant and the gate voltage mainly drops on gate oxide, where
E FS
$E_{\mathrm{FS}}$ is the Fermi level on the silicon surface. For an ideal oxide (without
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ and
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ ), when the oxide is thinner, the absolute
V G
@
E FS
=
E C
$V_{G}@E_{\mathrm{FS}}=E_{C}$ is relatively small. That is, the conduction band of thinner oxide will be pinned by Fermi level in a smaller applied voltage. However, the tendency of
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ in Fig. 1(a) is just the opposite. It is indicated that there are other factors affecting the kinked points. For our preliminary conjecture,
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ existing on the insulator/semiconductor interface and
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ existing in the insulator may be the key factors.

In the following, a theory with the consideration of
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ and
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ included with the experimental data was utilized to simulate the relationship between
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ and
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ to prove the above conjecture. Figure 3 shows the measured
C
$C$ –
V
$V$ characteristics of MOS(p) with oxide thickness of 2.1 and 1.9 nm at frequencies ranging from 1 k to 1 MHz. The inset shows the microstructure of MOS(p) utilized in high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). It shows that the oxide thickness of 2.1 nm obtained by the HRTEM is consistent with the one extracted by the
C
$C$ –
V
$V$ measurement. Moreover, it shows well-behaved
C
$C$ –
V
$V$ curves with negligible dispersion in accumulation region and stretch-out on both capacitors. However, an obvious hump could be observed near the flat-band voltage on both
C
$C$ –
V
$V$ curves as the dashed square points out. The thinner the oxide, the higher the hump and it means more interface traps exist in the SiO2/Si interface. From the measured
C
$C$ –
V
$V$ characteristics, the number of
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ and
Q eff
/ q
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}/q$ of different oxide thicknesses could be extracted as shown in Fig. 4. In order to characterize the interfacial properties for the MOS capacitors, the combined high-low frequency
C
$C$ –
V
$V$ curve technique which was first brought up by Castagn and Vapaillé [25, 26] is adopted in this work. The
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ ’s at
V FB
$V_{\mathrm{FB}}$ with different oxide thicknesses are obtained with values varying from
6.3 ×

11

$6.3\times10^{11} \mbox{ to } 1.23 \times10^{12}\mbox{ cm}^{-2}\,\mbox{eV}^{-1}$ . In addition, the extracted
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ in our work is negative due to the oxide growth technique, i.e., anodization. The number of interface traps at flat-band (
Q it
(
Ψ S
= 0 ) / q

Q eff

$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}/q$ are both decreasing with the oxide thickness. It is inferred that thinner SiO2 contains more weak spots and charges, or more oxide nonuniformity [27]. Furthermore, the theoretical semiconductor flat-band voltage is expressed as

$$ V_{\mathrm{FB}} = \varphi_{\mathrm{ms}} - \frac{Q_{\mathrm{eff}}}{C_{\mathrm{ox}}} - \frac{Q_{\mathrm{it}}(\psi_{S} = 0)}{C_{\mathrm{ox}}} $$ where
ϕ ms
$\phi_{\mathrm{ms}}$ is the ideal work function difference between metal Al and p-substrate Si. The experimental extracted values of
V FB
$V_{\mathrm{FB}}$ are all around −0.86 V. It is noticed that the ideal MOS(p)
V FB
$V_{\mathrm{FB}}$ value is −0.94 V in this work. Analyzing
Q eff

Q it
(
Ψ S
= 0 ) / q
$Q_{\mathrm{it}}(\varPsi_{S}=0)/q$ , we can find out that the variation with oxide thickness on
Q it
(
Ψ S
= 0 ) / q
$Q_{\mathrm{it}}(\varPsi_{S}=0)/q$ (45 %) is much more severe than on
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ (25 %). The anodization system adopted in this study to grow SiO2 dielectric has the function and feature to repair the dangling bond in SiO2/Si interface due to the self-readjusting nature of electric field during anodization. The thicker the oxide, the longer the growth time needed; that is, the better the ability to repair the imperfect bonds. Hence,
Q it
(
Ψ S
= 0 ) / q
$Q_{\mathrm{it}}(\varPsi_{S}=0)/q$ in thicker oxide will reduce tremendously compared with
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ . In other words, in thinner oxide, the enhanced
Q it
$Q_{\mathrm{it}}$ in addition to
Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ becomes important to the determination of critical voltages such as
V FB
$V_{\mathrm{FB}}$ and
V G
@

|

$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ .

As the forward bias increases from zero to negative, at first, most of the applied voltage drops on silicon surface and
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ nearly remains small. When the forward bias increases gradually, the silicon transits from depletion, flat-band, to accumulation, the applied voltage transforms to drop on silicon oxide dominantly and, in the meanwhile, the silicon surface potential almost remains constant instead. Here, we try to draw out the point of the exchange of dominant role between
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ and
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ with
V G
$V_{G}$ . The slope of the curves in Fig. 5(a) represents the variation of each term with gate voltage. As the dashed square points out, there is an identical slope of these two terms at this region, so we differentiate them and the derivative of both silicon surface potential (
Ψ S ′
$\varPsi_{S}'$ ) and silicon oxide voltage (
V ox ′
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}'$ ) versus gate voltage will be carried out as shown in Fig. 5(b). It is evident that
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ and
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ are competing with each other following
V G
$V_{G}$ and will be in a growth and decline relationship. At small forward bias, the variation of
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ is much larger than
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ . At this time, the tunneling probability through oxide is lightly dependent on the applied voltage. However, if the dominant role changes, the variation of
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ is much larger than
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ . At this time,
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ is almost pinned at the silicon valance band edge,
E V
$E_{V}$ . The Fermi level of metal,
E FM
$E_{\mathrm{FM}}$ , is much higher than silicon conduction band edge,
E C
$E_{C}$ , for several kT, therefore, more and more electrons in the metal have sufficient energy to tunnel into the silicon conduction band. In this case, the tunneling probability dominates the current level. We define
V G
@
E FS
=
E V
$V_{G}@E_{\mathrm{FS}}=E_{V}$ as the gate voltage when the values of
Ψ S ′
$\varPsi_{S}'$ and
V ox ′
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}'$ are identical. As the absolute gate bias is larger than
V G
@
E FS
=
E V
$V_{G}@E_{\mathrm{FS}}=E_{V}$ , it infers that the silicon band bending almost keeps constant and the bias starts to considerably drop on the silicon oxide.

D it

Q eff
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}$ play important roles in the behavior of gate leakage current.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
By observation, it was found that every
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve of MOS(p) has an obvious kinked point around −1 V. The relationship between
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ and
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ following
V G
$V_{G}$ on MOS(p) system with the realistic experimental values is comprehensively studied. The kinked voltage
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ , is inferred to
V G
@
E FS
=
E V
$V_{G}@E_{\mathrm{FS}}=E_{V}$ . When the absolute bias is larger than
V G
@
|
J G
|
min ′
$V_{G}@|J_{G}|'_{\min}$ ,
Ψ S
$\varPsi_{S}$ will not bend anymore, and the
V ox
$V_{\mathrm{ox}}$ with
V G
$V_{G}$ increase considerably. The kinked points discussed in this work are strongly dependent on oxide thickness,
D it
$D_{\mathrm{it}}$ , and
Q eff
/ q
$Q_{\mathrm{eff}}/q$ and are of importance to the study of current characteristics of ultra-thin oxides. On the other hand, this kinked phenomenon does not appear in the forward positive bias
J
$J$ –
V
$V$ curve of MOS(n). That is because the forward bias for MOS(n) is always accumulated and the gate voltage drops almost entirely on silicon oxide. The study of this work is fundamental and is of importance to characterize the quality of ultra-thin oxides.
